messages: 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:06): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: i might be here on irc during the telecon tomorrow, but in any case: i'm willing to help with test suite organization
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:12): ah. interesting.
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:15): any ideas on how to organize tests, 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 ?
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:16): I'm interested in tests materials that (a) aid developers in building good software, and (b) aid users in judging software and reporting problems
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:17): stuff that captures issues that people care about with objective results

587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:18): the GRDDL spec has a much smaller scope, but we came up with a few dozen tests and we have test results in machine-readable form from a handful of implementations. http://www.w3.org/2001/sw/grddl-wg/td/test_results
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:19): I expect we'll need several different kinds of tests for HTML
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:19): we'll be able to automate some parts more than others, I expect
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:31): too‚Ä¶ much‚Ä¶¬†spec‚Ä¶
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:32): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: haven't thought much about it yet
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:33): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: although we will have thousands of tests
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:33): (or already have)
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:34): too much spec for what?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:34): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: to review
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:35): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: concentrate on one thing at a time :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:35): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: I am
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:35): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: It still seems endless, though
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:36): some day I'll misspell "microsyntaxes" in the subject line of one of my emails‚Ä¶
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:36): I find it hard to believe that a BNF or regex isn't easier to specify and review than english prose for stuff like microsyntaxes. oh well.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:38): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: a lot of the requirements would end up being English prose anyway
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (21:38): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: perhaps we could just check in all tests at http://code.google.com/p/html5/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:38): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: all the various times when you exist the ratios algorithm. you'd end up with so many alternatives in BNF or regex
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:38): *exit
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:39): what's a few more alternatives? this is a rather mature part of computer science.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:40): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: take a look at #ratios, it isn't overly long, but I can't think of many easy ways of expressing that
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:42): I don't see anything that won't fit in a regex
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:42): It won't be an overly simple one though
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:42): I'd rather have prose than complex regex
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:43): you're doing the work, not me.

587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:44): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46, hosting at code.google.com might work, as long as we can keep a copy in w3.org somewhere too. does code.google.com offer an rsync interface?
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:44): I'd rather use a decentralized version control system like hg or bzr or git
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:44): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: and anne said that I was the person to ask if he ever needed an overly complex regex :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:48): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: I think that expresses the algorithm‚Ä¶
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:49): written out as BNF, it's probably quite straightforward
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:49): since, for example, [0123456789] gets factored out as <digit>
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:50): *DIGIT "." +DIGIT / +DIGIT "." *DIGIT / DIGIT covers a floating point number in ABNF, I think
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:50): It'll be simpler than URI's ABNF for certain though

587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:51): when you said "a lot of the requirements would end up being English prose anyway" I thought you were saying that there are constraints that can't be expressed in BNF. I don't see any so far.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:52): ratios probably isn't the best of examples
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:53): I think it's worth publishing BNF for these things, even if it has to be a separate document. I've got a handful of volunteers for the formalization task.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:53): dates would end up being verbose if you wanted to be exact (RFC3339's ABNF allows hours > 24, minutes > 59, seconds > 60)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:54): I've got nothing against publishing some sort of BNF, but I'd rather the prose were the only normative part of the standard
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:54): true, capturing leap year rules in regex's isn't worthwhile. \d\d\d\d-\d\d-\d\d plus some prose constraints is a happy medium.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:55): I liked BNF more before I started dealing with URIs and IRIs.
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:55): 3.2.3.4. Ratios doesn't motivate any of the complexity.

587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:56): the regex at the end of the URI spec works much better than the BNF. URIs aren't parsed top-down like programming languages; they're chopped up piece by piece
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:57): they aren't that nice when you do try and parse them without using regex
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:58): </complete:understatement>
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (21:58): URI syntax is particularly horrible, and it took a long time to figure out the bounds of the standard. (it's still ongoing).
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (22:00): I wonder where this %|Ÿ™|Ô?™|ÔºÖ|‚Ä?|‚Ä± stuff came from. Surely no cows blazed any path like that.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:00): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: it's allowed as content of elements
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (22:01): yes, but why bother with ‚Ä± ? is that really worthwhile? why go beyond one % character?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:01): hmm‚Ä¶ URIs predate me :\ (though I think any standards regarding URL/URIs are younger)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:01): 587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef: the arabic one is really used by arabic people.

587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (22:03): wild. I think it's best to return to my "I don't care what design you come up with, as long as there are plenty of tests and the implementors are willing to pass them" mode.
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (22:03): needs lunch
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (22:03): is late for a telcon :-/
